availability.p: The text of the original document is in the public domain. Subject to certain exceptions, public domain works may be freely copied or used in the creation of derivative works without permission, or authorization, of the former copyright owners.

The text encoding was created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and is governed by a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

note.p: Manuscript of "Note at end of Complete Poems and Prose," published in Complete Poems & Prose (1888) and not reprinted during Whitman's lifetime.

bibl.author: Whitman, Walt
bibl.title: Note at End
bibl.orgName: The Charles E. Feinberg Collection of the Papers of Walt Whitman, 1839-1919, Library of Congress, Washington, DC.
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.
The verso is comprised of approximately six different segments of paper pasted together. These segments include blank sheets, typed pages, and handwritten notes by Whitman.

body.note: To Printer — Set in L P close (like the rest) I want it to come in two pages — you might as well make up before you send me the proof. — The head might be plain O S caps —? ab't pica)
body.p:
As I conclude — and (to get typographical correctness,)after running ‸my esses diligently through the three big divisions of the preceding Volume — The ‸interrogative wonder⹀⹀fancy rises in me whether (if it be not too arrogant to ‸even claimstate it,) the 3833 years of thismy current time, 1858–1888, with their aggregate of our New World historydoings & people, have not ‸really created and form–
ulatedformulated
the foregoing pages — forcing their utterance
as the pages stand — coming actually from thisthe direct urge ‸and developementsdevelopments, of those years and not from any individual epic or lyrical attempt whatever, or from my pen or voice, or any body's special voice. FromOut of that suppo–
sitionsupposition the Book
— or might assume to be considered — an typical emotionalautochthonic record and expression freely render'd, and in spirit before letter and from their own radical genesis of and out of these 30 to 35 years — of the deedssoul and soul developementdevelopmentand evolution of America — and of course, by reflection, more or less of the common spirit and common people of the world. Or it may be I would not let the great and momentous era of these years, these States, slip away without attempting to arrest in a special printed book some few specimens — even vital breaths — as representa–
tivesrepresentatives of it all from my point of view, and from the most of it, and, at the time...

¶ Then a few additional words yet to this hurried farewell note. In another sense (the warp crossing the woof, and knitted in) the Book is probably a sort of autobiography; an element I have not attempted to specially restrain or erase. ‸As alluded to at beginning I spoke at be–
ginningbeginning this edition of
